w:r.w:t: AI Self and Peer Evaluation System

The purpose of this document is to define the design decisions, system architecture, and data flow of APEER, ensuring a clear understanding for developers, testers, and stakeholders. It serves as a reference for the implementation, integration, and maintenance of the system.
– To implement the system based on the architecture and component specifications.
– To validate system behavior and ensure it meets design requirements.
– To review and guide the project’s technical and design aspects.
APEER is a web-based evaluation platform designed to:
Automate the collection and analysis of peer and self-evaluations.
to classify comments, detect sentiment, and summarize feedback.
Provide dashboards for students (personal growth) and teachers (class analytics/bias detection).
Operate as a standalone system integrated with
AI Self and Peer Evaluation System (APEER)
aims to provide a fair, efficient, and intelligent evaluation process for students in academic settings. The system leverages
to analyze, summarize, and evaluate peer and self-assessments, ensuring constructive and unbiased feedback.
for both students and teachers. It integrates with
: Using AI to support students’ feedback provision...

The primary interface for students to submit peer feedback. It includes a text area with real-time validation to ensure comments meet the minimum character count before submission. It handles the display of success messages or error alerts upon submission.
A JavaScript module responsible for handling all HTTP requests related to evaluation submissions. It uses Axios to send data to the backend and handle responses asynchronously.
): Sends the student's feedback payload (target student ID, comment text, rubric scores) to the backend.
(text): Client-side helper to check if the comment length meets the requirement (e.g., > 20 characters).
Exposes REST API endpoints to receive evaluation submissions. It validates the incoming DTO, triggers the classification service, and returns the processing status to the client.
Contains the business logic for saving evaluations. It orchestrates the call to the AI Microservice for classification and persists the result in the database.
A Data Transfer Object used to encapsulate the submission data sent from the frontend. Contains fields for
Java Spring Boot Data Transfer Object (DTO)
A specialized service that acts as a bridge to the Python AI Microservice. It sends raw text via HTTP POST and receives classified tags (e.g., "Constructive", "Vague").
Represents the database entity for a single comment. Stores the content, timestamp, and the list of tags assigned by the AI.
A visual component used in the Teacher Dashboard to display the quality score of a comment. It renders a color-coded bar (Green/Yellow/Red) based on the "Usefulness Score" returned by the backend.
Orchestrates the analysis workflow. It retrieves unanalyzed comments from the database and sends them to the Python Microservice for scoring.
DTO used to transfer analysis results between the AI service and the backend. Contains
Java Spring Boot Data Transfer Object (DTO)
A Python script running within the Flask microservice. It utilizes libraries like
or VADER to calculate sentiment polarity and custom logic to compute a "Usefulness Score" (0-100).
Entity class that stores the numerical analysis results linked to a specific Comment entity.
A UI card component that displays the AI-generated summary. It organizes text into "Strengths," "Weaknesses," and "Key Themes" for easy reading by the student.
Handles API calls to fetch the generated summary for a specific student.
): Retrieves the pre-calculated summary JSON object for the logged-in student.
Responsible for aggregating all "Valid" comments for a target student and preparing them for the AI model. It filters out low-quality comments before processing.
Encapsulates the generated summary sections (strengths, weaknesses, suggestions) to be sent to the frontend.
Java Spring Boot Data Transfer Object (DTO)
The AI endpoint that accepts a list of comment strings and uses a Transformer model (e.g., BART/T5) to generate a cohesive abstractive summary.
The main landing page for students. It acts as a container for various widgets, including the
Fetches all necessary metrics for the dashboard in a single or parallel API call.
): Fetches average scores, completion rates, and recent activity.
): Retrieves historical sentiment data for visualization.
Exposes read-only endpoints specifically aggregated for the student view.
Computes statistical averages and trends from raw evaluation data stored in the database.
A DTO containing aggregated fields like
Displays a data table of all students in a class, with sortable columns for "Participation Rate," "Average Score," and "Bias Flags."
A UI badge or icon that appears next to a student's name if their evaluation scores are statistically anomalous (outliers).
Service module for fetching class-wide analytics.
): Returns aggregated data for the entire class.
): Returns a list of evaluations flagged for potential bias.
Secure endpoints accessible only by users with the ROLE_TEACHER authority.
Implements statistical algorithms (e.g., Standard Deviation checks) to identify scores that deviate significantly from the class norm.
A form interface where teachers can define a new evaluation event. Inputs include "Activity Title," "Deadline," "Rubric Selection," and "Target Group."
Handles the creation and management of evaluation activities.
): POST request to create a new evaluation event.
): Fetches available rubrics for the teacher to select.
Handles POST requests to create new evaluation events and assigns them to student groups.
Entity representing the event itself (e.g., "Midterm Peer Review"), including metadata like deadline and active status.
Entity representing the scoring criteria (e.g., "Teamwork", "Communication") used in an activity.
A component that initiates the OAuth2 flow by redirecting the user to the Google Consent Screen.
): Sends the Google authorization code to the backend to exchange for a JWT.
): Clears the stored JWT and redirects to the login page.
Handles the callback from Google, verifies the email domain (@cit.edu), creates the user if they don't exist, and issues the system JWT.
Utility class for generating, signing, and validating JSON Web Tokens (JWT) used for session management.
DTO returned upon successful login, containing token, email, role, and name.

A simple administrative interface that displays a list of registered system users. The interface presents non-sensitive user information such as name, email address, role (Student or Teacher), and account status (Active or Inactive). The administrator can activate or deactivate user accounts as part of access control and maintenance.

Provides secure REST endpoints accessible only to users with the ROLE_ADMIN authority. Handles requests for retrieving user lists and updating account status. The controller enforces strict access boundaries to prevent administrative access to evaluation or AI-related resources.
Implements business logic for fetching user metadata and updating account activation status. Ensures that administrative actions are restricted to user account management only.
A lightweight Data Transfer Object used to expose non-sensitive user information to the administrator interface. Fields include
Java Spring Boot Data Transfer Object (DTO)
Existing system entity representing registered users. This module interacts only with authentication-related attributes such as role and account status.
